Congratulations. I'm happy you were able to get your EJB's tested using JUnit!
 
I would caution you, however... If this is going to be a large project, then you'll have to start servers to test your EJB's and you'll have to re-start often when debugging.
 
I'd like to suggest an alternative. Just create an instance of your stateful EJB directly. You won't have connection to the container, container managed persistence, etc. But if you're not using a data source or entity beans, you can get away without using a container. It has the following benefits:
Debugging does not require a server
Running does not require a server
Faster testing (because you don't need the server)
There are some downsides:
You are not testing the code in its actual deployment environment
If you do start using a datasource, container transactions, entity beans, etc., you will need to change your test to use the bean in a container.
You might forget to use the container and do something like have the bean call itself in the actual code, which will not work in the container.
But consider it. If the project goes on for a number of years, the small decisions you make today will have a huge impact later on. (From personal experience.)
 
If this becomes an issue, use Spring.
 
Brett

"Brett L. Schuchert" <schuchert@yahoo. com> wrote:
Yes. We've been doing it for 3+ years.

The key is getting the right combination of jar files and property files in your class path. Once you've done that, you can connect to an EJB and send it a message. No problem.

However, I'd caution you to not do that if you can avoid it. 

I understand that you are testing the use of the code more closely to the environment in which it will run. On the other hand, you now will need to run a server to run your unit tests. They will be a bit more of a pain to debug (though they are certainly debug-able).

We are using stateful session beans (I can give you the reasons for it if you'd like, but suffice it to say we are doing that). We then introduce entity beans because, frankly, WebSphere's handling of stateful session beans was wholly inadequate (and I can explain that - this was for WAS 5.0 - 5.1, have not experimented with WAS 6.0 or 6.1 yet). Since we started using entity beans, we started using server side tests. Now we have a whole lot of tests that require a server. 

Well we're moving away from that. We're replacing all of our entity beans (about 6 coarse-grained beans) with hibernate. We are moving all logic out of stateful session beans into POJO's so the session beans are just pass through. Then we'll use spring to configure the system.

This allows for quick testing without having to have a server running (better support for continuous integration only because it removes an excuse for people to check in without running all unit tests - not really a good reason but it can help). ALSO, if you move to WAS 6.0 and RAD 6.0, deployment can be VERY slow (up to 15 minutes and beyond for a moderate system), which makes testing even more of a pain BUT NO LESS ESSENTIAL.

I understand that to be pragmatic you probably need a solution now and might consider allowing tests to run without having to use a server.

I won't be able to get back to you with any details until next week (I'm about to leave on a vacation). But if you send me the following information, I'll try to give you the details that might get you there:
- Version of WAS
- Your IDE, if any (WSAD, RAD, Eclipse + WTP, ...) and the version number of that IDE

As an alternative, you can try this right now:
1. Start a server.
2. Run the universal test client to look at the JNDI tree
3. Find where your beans are actually deployed: cell/nodes/server/ server1/. .. (or something like that, don't have the info handy)
4. Use Sun's JNDI instead of IBM's
5. Point to the correct port, 2809 for WAS 5.1, 2810 for WAS 6.x
6. If you are looking for a session bean called FooHome, add cell/nodes/server/ server1/ in front of it.

Hope that's enough to get you started. I can get more to you next week.
